4.text:
Jennifer Scott:– We are lucky to have today
Jordan Mearns, who is in his final year doing

9.text:
his PhD at the University of Edinburgh. Jordan’s
PhD subject looks at the aesthetics of Britishness

16.text:
in the reign of George III. A serious subject
indeed! And yet the title of Jordan’s paper

23.text:
today made me laugh out loud when I saw it.
I, as a museum director, spend a lot of time

28.text:
thinking about endowments, about the size
of the endowment of the Holburne Museum, but

32.text:
today we’re looking at a slightly different
type of endowment, although I understand size

36.text:
is still important, Jordan.
So Jordan’s title for today is Behind the

39.text:
Curtain and Under the Kilt: The Earl of Bute,
his Endowment, and the Full-Length (of it).

47.text: Jordan, over to you. Thank you.

54.text:
Jordan Mearns:– Thank you very much. I’d
like to begin by briefly thanking the organisers

60.text:
of this conference. I’m starting my stop
watch. And noting that this paper is drawn

65.text:
from a longer chapter in my PhD. I’m sorry,
I hope it hasn’t suffered too much in compression.

71.text:
And my paper will be woven around two full
length portraits painted by Allan Ramsay in

76.text:
the late 1750s of George III as Prince of
Wales, and that of the prince’s dearest

82.text:
friend, courtier, and eventually spectacularly
unpopular Prime Minister, John Stuart, 3rd

87.text:
Earl of Bute.
These reciprocal commissions are the products

92.text:
of a formative period in the prince and Bute’s
controversial and polarising relationship,

97.text:
which dominated political discourse in the
years immediately before and after George’s

101.text:
accession to the throne in 1760.
Bute commissioned a portrait of the prince

108.text:
in late 1757/8, by which time he had already
ruffled court feathers having been installed

114.text:
as the Groom of the Stool, the most senior
position in the heir to the throne’s household.

120.text:
Prince George returned the gesture by commissioning
a portrait of Bute the same year, initiating

125.text:
a close association with Ramsay, which would
result in a series of formal portrait commissions

130.text:
of the royal family, including the highly
lucrative coronation portrait commission which

135.text:
involved the production of innumerable copies,
and eventually Ramsay’s appointment to the

139.text:
office of Principal Painter-in-Ordinary to
George III in 1761.

144.text:
George’s sustained patronage of Ramsay was
construed as proof of the charges laid at

150.text:
Bute’s door that he was instrumental in
procuring lucrative positions for his fellow

155.text:
Scots through his purportedly unseemly behind
the curtain influence over the young king

161.text:
and prince.
After cataloguing a succession of prominent

165.text:
Scottish appointments in the royal household,
court, and in public offices in the early

169.text:
years of George’s reign, the anonymous author
of a bitterly Scotophobic invective pamphlet

174.text:
entitled ‘Le Montagnard Parvenu’ highlights
the king’s suspect patronage.

181.text:
The title of the pamphlet, ‘Le Montagnard
Parvenu’. ‘Le Montagnard’, French for

187.text:
mountaineer is a term associated with Jacobites
in this period of the eighteenth century,

193.text:
and ‘parvenu’ is self-explanatory.
The author writes: “Had not every English

199.text:
subject reason to stare at finding their beloved
young King’s picture painted by Ramsay,

203.text:
and not by the Apelles hands of Reynolds;
and the reason is obvious, the former is a

208.text:
Scot and the latter an Englishman. Ramsay,
for anything we may know, may be as honest

213.text:
and worthy a man as any in society, but it
cannot, we hope, amount to any misprision

217.text:
of treason to say that Reynolds is a more
masterly painter, and were Alexander alive

222.text:
would be chosen by him in preference to the
other.”

227.text:
The author of the pamphlet seizes upon Ramsay’s
royal patronage as symptomatic of wider political

231.text:
concerns surrounding Bute’s supposed influence
and rise to high office. Counterpointing London’s

238.text:
two leading portraitists, Ramsay and Reynolds,
in national, rather than artistic, terms echoes

243.text:
the widespread anti-Scottish sentiment of
the 1760s. Most famously mobilised by John

248.text:
Wilkes in the periodical, The North Briton.
The inclusion of Ramsay in the pamphlet also

254.text:
hints at the intense but downplayed rivalry
between Ramsay and Sir Joshua Reynolds at

258.text:
this juncture in their careers. It’s worth
noting that Reynolds never received a direct

263.text:
commission from King George despite being
appointed First President of the Royal Academy.

267.text:
And an example of this (underplayed, I’d
say) rivalry between the two artists is this

274.text:
portrait which Reynolds produced speculatively
of George III. It was never accepted. And

281.text:
in this portrait I think there’s a very
definite attempt on Reynold’s part to appropriate

286.text:
the style of Ramsay. This is one of the closest
examples to Ramsay’s style, I think, you

292.text:
can find in Reynolds’s output.
The procurement of reproductive prints of

299.text:
the portrait of the young prince was similarly
drawn into the realm of broader national politics.

304.text:
The task of engraving the portraits was offered
by Ramsay - but subsequently declined - by

308.text:
his countryman, the engraver, Robert Strange.
Strange’s impolitic decline of this royal

314.text:
commission inspired charges of disloyalty
to the Hanoverian crown.

318.text:
And a permanent breach in the artists’ relationship
are rated in a series of frenzied letters

323.text:
between the artists and points to the fraught
nature of this episode, and to the lingering

329.text:
spectre of Jacobitism in the 1760s, also hinting
at the fragility of Anglo-Scottish relations

336.text:
in the period.
Thus despite their conventional formality,

340.text:
these seemingly innocuous and remote portraits
served as a focal point around which broader

346.text:
political issues coalesced, and thus offer
a rich seam of interpretive potential.

352.text:
The intermingling of the realms of art and
national politics chimes well with Holger

356.text:
Hoock’s observation in his detailed Institutional
History of the Royal Academy (quote) “That

363.text:
discussion of the arts, artists’ activities,
and institutional politics reflected are contributed

368.text:
to wider political discourses.
The troublesome scandals mentioned above and

373.text:
the fraught politics of royal patronage are
important expressions of the interface between

378.text:
art and politics which predate the foundation
of the Royal Academy in 1768 and provide at

384.text:
least in part an explanation for why Ramsay
so conspicuously distanced himself from that

389.text:
institution.
The two prestigious full length portraits

394.text:
of Prince George and Bute occupy a pivotal
role in the establishment of Ramsay’s career,

399.text:
serving as a platform to examine Ramsay’s
cultivation of courtly patronage, and rise

403.text:
through the artistic ranks.
However, as visual documents, the portraits

407.text:
are surprisingly mute, approached as little
more than conventional courtly portraits.

412.text:
At this stage, I wish to return again to the
portrait of Bute itself and tease out an oblique

420.text:
relationship between it and one particular
scandal, a courtly intrigue involving Bute

426.text:
which surfaced in 1755-6, and proliferated
in an extraordinary deluge of satirical imagery

432.text:
and political polemic throughout the period
of Bute’s political ascendancy until his

438.text:
eventual resignation in 1763.
Bute’s sway and rise to power in the young

445.text:
Prince of Wales’s household was deeply contentious.
Having beaten the presumed candidate for the

450.text:
Groom of the Stool, to the top job, rumours
began to circulate regarding the circumstances

455.text:
of his hasty ascendancy.
Bute’s closeness with the prince’s mother,

460.text:
Augusta, Dowager Princess of Wales, was widely
suspected as the source of his preferment.

466.text:
The Earl of Chesterfield, who chronicled the
closeness between Bute and the prince, commented

471.text:
that Bute, “entirely engrossed, not only
the affections, but even the sense of the

477.text:
young prince who seemed to have made a total
surrender of them to Lord Bute”. Chesterfield

482.text:
continues, “The scandalous chronicle says,
that he was still a greater favourite with

488.text:
the Princess of Wales: I will not nor cannot
decide upon the fact. It is certain on the

494.text:
one hand that there were many strong indications
of the tenderest connection between them.”

499.text:
The Earl of Waldegrave, whom Bute displaced
as Groom of the Stool, noted in his gossipy

505.text:
and salacious memoirs, that Bute was, “...above
the middle size, had broad shoulders, great

513.text:
muscular strength, and remarkable fine legs”.
Marshalling Bute’s desirable physicality

519.text:
is ammunition for his scandalous insinuations,
Waldegrave goes on to hint, referring to Princess

525.text:
Augusta, “that these bodily perfections
sometimes may have attracted vulgar widows.”

530.text:
Bute’s fine legs became a leitmotif in the
attacks of his political enemies. Strikingly,

538.text:
detailed descriptions of his physique, particularly
his legs, appear repeatedly in the memoirs

543.text:
and correspondence of several of his contemporaries.
For example, in Horace Walpole’s ‘Memoirs

551.text:
of ...George III’, where Walpole sneers:
“the favoured personage, naturally ostentatious

559.text:
of his person and of haughty carriage, seemed
by no means desirous of concealing his conquest.

565.text:
His bows grrw more theatric, his graces contracted
some meaning, and the beauty of his leg was

571.text:
constantly displayed in the eyes of the poor
captivated princess.”

576.text:
Walpole continues: “the eagerness of the
pages of the backstairs to let her know whenever

583.text:
Lord Bute arrived, a mellowness in her German
accent as often as she spoke to him, and that

589.text:
was often and long, and a more than usual
swimmingness in her eyes, contributed to dispel

594.text:
the ideas that had been conceived of the rigour
of her widowhood.”

599.text:
Both aristocratic analysts eroticise Bute’s
legs, casting them as a noteworthy facet of

605.text:
his physique and key to his seduction of the
princess. Sir Nathaniel Wraxall, diarist and

612.text:
author, also mentions Lord Bute’s legs in
his memoirs, noting particularly how his physique

619.text:
played a role in the critiques of his enemies.
He writes: “Lord Bute, when young, possessed

625.text:
a very handsome person of which advantage
he was not insensible, and he used to pass

630.text:
many hours every day, as his enemies asserted,
occupied in contemplating the symmetry of

636.text:
his own legs during his solitary walks by
the side of the Thames.”

642.text:
The significance of Lord Bute’s well-developed
and alluring legs is memorably chronicled

647.text:
in an anecdote relating to his sitting for
Allan Ramsay’s full length portrait. The

653.text:
painter and engraver, Thomas Smith, recalls
in his work, ‘Nollekens and His Times’:

662.text:
“I once heard Ramsay the painter say that
Lord Bute’s leg was allowed to be the handsomest

667.text:
in England, and that whilst he was standing
to him for his whole-length portrait, engraved

672.text:
by Ryland, that his lordship held up his robes
considerably above the right knee so that

677.text:
his leg should be entirely seen, in which
position he remained for the space of an hour.

682.text:
And, it is a very remarkable fact that the
forefinger of the hand supporting the robe

687.text:
is pointing down the leg.”
Going on, the same author, John Thomas Smith,

695.text:
relates an anecdote in which he again foregrounds
the professional rivalry between Allan Ramsay

700.text:
and Sir Joshua Reynolds, this time in terms
of their depiction of male legs in which the

705.text:
latter tries to outdo Ramsay in the depiction
and celebration of exquisite aristocratic

710.text:
legs; “When the marquis of Rockingham was
standing to Sir Joshua Reynolds for his whole-length

715.text:
portrait engraved by Fisher, his lordship
asked the painter if he had not given a strut

720.text:
to the left leg. ‘My Lord’, replied Sir
Joshua, ‘I wish to show a leg with Ramsay’s

726.text:
‘Lord Bute’’.”
In Ramsay’s portrait… I jump around a

731.text:
bit, sorry.
In Ramsay’s portrait, Bute’s celebrated

735.text:
legs indeed play a conspicuous role. In the
portrait, Bute’s gleaming white silk stockings

740.text:
stand out against the shadows of his flowing
robes. His nonchalant cross-legged stance,

746.text:
expressive of refined masculinity, also allows
for the maximum exposure. One leg is presented

752.text:
frontly, the other delineated side-on, thus
affording an in-the-round view and emphasising

759.text:
the ample swell of Bute’s well-developed
calf muscles.

762.text:
As flagged by Smith, Bute’s left hand which
gathers his robes, so we might better admire

768.text:
his full calves, is posed so that the index
finger points downwards. This gesture imparts

776.text:
a graceful downward sweep to the composition
and also reads visually as a command, seemingly

782.text:
inviting us to admire the legs that Bute so
conscientiously exposes to our view.

788.text:
A further moment of compositional intricacy
results from Bute’s strategic robe gathering.

794.text:
As Ramsay scholars are keen to point out,
the artist lavish much attention on sitter’s

800.text:
hands, investing them with meaning and compositional
importance. Thus it seems justified to read,

807.text:
if heuristically, into this seemingly incidental
detail played out on the canvas.

814.text:
In the process of gathering up his robes to
showcase his legs, a corner of ermine-edged

824.text:
red velvet forms a triangular swathe of material
which casts a pool of shadow and serves to

830.text:
decorously obscure and de-emphasise Bute’s
groin.

834.text:
At the heart of Ramsay’s portrait then,
there seems to be a deftly articulated and

840.text:
precisely orchestrated tension between display
and obfuscation. In one graceful gesture Bute

848.text:
simultaneously reveals and decorously conceals.
Joseph Monteyne devotes a chapter in his recent

857.text:
study, ‘From Still Life to the Screen’,
to the visual trope of the screen in eighteenth

862.text:
century visual culture, in which he argues
for a similar tension. Monteyne writes that

868.text:
the screen serves to conceal but paradoxically
can also reveal more than it hides by calling

874.text:
attention to the very process of obfuscation.
The corner of ermine-trimmed velvet which

880.text:
obscures Bute’s groin functions in a similar
way to Monteyne’s screen, paradoxically

886.text:
serving to emphasise an area of Bute’s physicality
which was to become a regular feature in the

893.text:
extraordinary deluge of graphic satires with
which he was harangued in the 1760s.

899.text:
Among such images, Sawney Discover’d, or,
The Scotch Intruders is a salacious and formerly

905.text:
innovative example, which dramatizes the alleged
relationship between Bute and the Dowager

911.text:
Princess of Wales by employing this trope
of the screen.

916.text:
At first glance, Sawney Discover’d depicts
a motley procession of Scots, identifiable

921.text:
by obligatory swathes of tartan and Scotch
bonnets. The figures are being shepherded

927.text:
by Lord Bute behind a screen which is emblazoned
with a pattern of thistles. Again, a very

933.text:
conventional image of Scottishness. The screen
bears the Latin motto of The Order of the

938.text:
Thistle, ‘nemo me impune lacessit’, ‘no
one touches me with impunity’, which is

944.text:
re-rendered in English as, ‘no one touches
me but gets the itch’, imbuing the august

950.text:
motto with a slant of venereal disease.
Lord Bute, clutching a scrap of paper upon

956.text:
which is written, List of Scots Gents to Fill
up any Vacancy, says to his cohort, ‘Come

964.text:
lads, I’ll take you behind the screen if
you shall show all your parts to the lady’.

970.text:
Here, the slippage between parts as credentials
and genitals is clearly intentional. The followers,

979.text:
figures in kilts, variously reply, ‘I’ll
show my great talent’, ‘I have a large

985.text:
recommendation besides my impudence’, continuing
the double entendre relating to penis size.

992.text:
Just as the Latin motto is imbued with references
to venereal disease, the printed dialogue

997.text:
revels in body innuendo deploying obvious
double entendre which operate by cleverly

1003.text:
juggling allegations of placement, corruption
and favouritism, whilst hinting at penis size.

1010.text:
The image, therefore, operates by pithily
vacillating between corruption in a sexual

1015.text:
and political sense.
Recalling Charles Churchill’s memorable

1019.text:
lines about the voracity of Scots on the make
in London, “...Into our places, states,

1024.text:
and beds they creep; They’ve sense to get,
what we want sense to keep.”

1030.text:
When backlit…and you’ll notice at the
bottom of the slide is a little text which

1038.text:
says, ‘be understood this must be held to
the light’...when backlit, the viewer is

1042.text:
granted a glimpse behind the screen where
the conceit of the image becomes clear. When

1048.text:
held to the light an image printed on the
verso shines through the screen to represent

1054.text:
Bute and the dowager princess in flagrante.
She clutches a large thistle, saying, ‘Bye-bye,

1061.text:
I serve you all that I will, Sawney’, to
which he replies, ‘I must be in your favour

1067.text:
to gain my ends.’
In the image the screen performs a number

1071.text:
of narrative functions. Firstly it suggests
courtly intrigue in a general sense, revelling

1077.text:
in what Frank O’Gorman has designated (quote)
“the myth of Lord Bute’s secret influence”.

1084.text:
Alongside a critique of Bute’s alleged backstage
machinations, which the print literalises

1090.text:
in its very form, the image narrates the improper
relationship between the Earl of Bute and

1095.text:
the Princess Dowager, suggesting Bute’s
capacity to procure through sexual favours

1101.text:
beneficial places for fellow Scotsmen.
In this image, the outsize thistle which Augusta

1107.text:
clutches is more than a straightforward phallic
surrogate. I would argue that the thistle

1113.text:
operates on a more potent symbolic level.
The thistle is the hitch pin which binds the

1119.text:
national, political, and sexual strands of
the image together. Instantly recognisable

1125.text:
as visual shorthand for Scottishness, the
thistle is here symbolically conflated with

1130.text:
the penis, serving to equivocate between the
sexual and political strands of the image.

1137.text:
This suggestive visual polysemy deploy textually
in the slippage between the word ‘parts’

1144.text:
as a sustained presence in anti-Bute imagery,
written and graphic, in which symbols of Scotland

1150.text:
are anthropomorphised and become synonymous
with the penis.

1155.text:
Sawney Discover’d thus relies upon a salacious
co-mingling of the discourses of nation and

1161.text:
of sexuality. Returning to the pamphlet mentioned
earlier, ‘Le Montagnard Parvenu’, the

1168.text:
author quotes the following lines from Shakespeare’s
‘Julius Caesar’, Ye gods it doth amaze

1175.text:
me,’ but I’m going to focus on, ‘Why
man he doth bestride our narrow world, Like

1180.text:
a Colossus, and we petty men, Walk under his
huge legs, and peep about, To find ourselves

1187.text:
dishonourable graves’.
Again, the legs crop up constantly in anti-Bute

1192.text:
material in the 1760s.
In this excerpt, Cassius bemoans Caesar’s

1198.text:
burgeoning power, likening Caesar to the Colossus
of Rhodes, the gargantuan statue of Apollo,

1204.text:
which reputedly straddled the harbour, and
was so large as to allow ships to pass between

1208.text:
its legs. In ‘Le Montagnard’ the Colossus
becomes a reification of Bute’s political

1215.text:
power.
The author introduces the quote by writing…

1219.text:
The author provides the quote with an explanatory
note, however, which loads the quotation from

1225.text:
Shakespeare with ribald innuendo. The note
reads: “If it were the fashion to wear this

1233.text:
chieftain’s [Bute’s] original dress at
court, those who Lilliputian-like should walk

1238.text:
under his Gulliverian legs might make a faithful
report to the public to the extent of that

1243.text:
merit by which he is reputed to have stood
so long in the lady’s favour.”

1250.text:
This body gloss is rendered visually in a
print of the same year entitled ‘The Scotch

1255.text:
Colossus or the beautys of ye Bagpipe’.
In this crude engraving, both in terms of

1263.text:
content and style, Bute, donning a kilt, stands
splay legged on two poles which emerge from

1270.text:
a pair of giant boots. The boots are a play
on the phonetic similarity of ‘Bute’ and

1275.text:
‘boot’ which became a rebus-like emblem
for Bute.

1280.text:
Between his leg, Bute dangles a sagging bagpipe,
the bag of which denotes a large scrotum,

1286.text:
the pipe an enormous flaccid penis. A speech-bubble
issuing form Bute’s mouth reads, ‘I’ll

1293.text:
straddle o’er the English’, a clear sexual
innuendo which again serves to suggest both

1297.text:
his sexual and political dominion over the
English.

1301.text:
Beneath him, arms outstretched, the Dowager
Princess of Wales stands gazing upwards, his

1307.text:
kilt affording her a clear prospect of his
enormous genitals. A speech-bubble rising

1313.text:
from her mouth reads, ‘I’d sacrifice all
for his bag pipe, oh, he’s my dear Rhezzio.'

1320.text:
The text underlines Augusta’s sexual desire
for Bute likening him to Rizzio, i.e. David

1326.text:
Rizzio, the courtier and favourite (and reputed
lover) of Mary Queen of Scots.

1331.text:
The bagpipe, like the thistle mentioned before,
is used for visual shorthand for Scottishness

1337.text:
and is likewise transmogrified into an enormous
penis.

1343.text:
In these prints Bute’s Scottishness and
his penis are distilled into one potent symbol,

1348.text:
the semiology of Scottishness itself becomes
connotative of unruly virility, sexual prowess

1354.text:
and political power. The imputed affair between
Bute and the Dowager Princess is more than

1361.text:
an example of eighteenth-century sexual reportage,
but a microcosmic analogy of national politics.

1368.text:
What, however, are the broader implications
of the Bute/Princess Augusta scandal and the

1375.text:
imagery that surrounds it?
So, I’m going to move into my conclusion

1378.text:
which is very compressed.
Anglo-Scottish relations were figuratively

1383.text:
gendered. In the period leading up to and
after the Union of 1707, writers routinely

1388.text:
likened the Anglo-Scottish Union to a marriage.
This metaphor was capacious enough to be recruited

1395.text:
by both pro- and anti-union counterparts.
In the Union-as-marriage metaphor, Scotland

1401.text:
was variously a venerable woman to be courted
by England, or a poor woman who had tricked

1407.text:
an illustrious husband into an improper match.
She was either part of an equal marriage of

1413.text:
affection, or a woman denuded of her independence
by a constrictive partner, now subservient

1420.text:
to England.
Regardless of the way in which the marriage

1423.text:
metaphor was slanted in terms of gender roles,
Scotland is always the bride with England

1430.text:
cast as her suitor. The feminisation of Scotland
was predicated on her inferior size and disparity

1436.text:
in terms of wealth and power.
The visual imagery surrounding Lord Bute heralds

1442.text:
the emergence of an arresting figurative volte-face
in which a consistently feminised Scotland

1448.text:
as bride morphed into an errant, threatening
and virile man. The suggestive polysemousness

1456.text:
of symbols of Scotland, the thistle and the
bagpipe’s emergent capacity to represent

1461.text:
both the nation as a whole and the penis are
indicative of this transformation.

1467.text:
The figurative vacillation between feminised
Scotland and Scotland as aggressively masculinised

1476.text:
points to Scotland’s shape-shifting from
bride to sexually aggressive male, which in

1480.text:
turn charts Scotland’s increasing sway south
of the border.

1484.text:
And I would like to, if I can, finish with
an image taken from an august Scottish newspaper,

1491.text:
The Record, which points to the contemporary
ramifications of my research.

1498.text:
Pointing to the fact that male bodies still
have the capacity to iterate national difference.
